Replies.Reply: You don't say! Dead?
Yeah, I coulda knocked you over with a pin.
Say, listen - I just heard something that'll make your head swim . . . Listen to this . . . Yeah, the bank was robbed last night. Yeah, over a hundred thousand dollars.
Come on, come on, Oscar, what are we waiting for?
I'm okay, Matt.
Yeah, what did he do with his first one?
Hey, psst!
And blowing no good for the old man, either.
The check is no good.
I guess so.
Charlie's upstairs as sore as a pup. He's out fourteen cents, and he can't find it.
Say, he did look kinda funny yesterday, didn't you notice it?
Closing your account?
I need some more money! All of the depositors are withdrawing.
Er, is this your signature?
I'm sorry, but I'll have to verify it.
Certainly, Mr. Jones! Certainly! Charlie!
Where's Matt?
It's a cinch bet. I wouldn't take it.
Say, if it had lipstick on it, he'd find it!
Nine o'clock and all is lousy!
Probably upstairs thinking up that daily joke.
Say Matt, I'll have to have some money for those Manville payrolls.
About twenty-four thousand.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Ten bucks? Say, if I had ten bucks, I'd quit.
Yeah?
Whose death?
Say pal, did you ever hear of a Depression?
Come over and see us sometime.
Where do you think I've been?
I took the baby for a stroll in the park.
I'm fourteen cents out, and it took me half an hour to find the mistake. And me with a date, too.
Yeah.
Say, don't annoy me. I got troubles of my own.
Oscar, what's the matter?
No kidding?
Where's Matt?
Yeah. He'll have a tough time thinking up a wise-crack for this one . . .
He has?
Nine o'clock and all is lousy.
Ten to one he'll have a crack about the run yesterday.
Oh, oh. Five ill winds.
Say, Matt! Matt! Did you hear the news?
Pardon me. All the big shots are in a huddle, and it looks like Dickson's out on his ear.
No, I'm not kidding. Everybody's talking about it. Ask her.
Sure, everybody's talking about it.
Well, I just thought I'd drop by and cheer you up a bit.
I'll be seeing you, Matt - in the breadline.
I was the first one to see it. I was coming down the stairs, and there was the dead watchman at my feet. You coulda knocked me over with a pin.
Do you see that clock? Right there. That's where the bullet hit. When I saw that, you coulda knocked me over with a pin.
Blood!
Come on over fellas. I'll show you.
I was the first one to see it. I was coming down the stairs, and there was the watchman lying dead at my feet.
No kidding. When I saw it, you coulda knocked me over with a pin.
Matt?
The detectives got Matt up there in Sampson's office.
Yeah.
Don't look at me. I don't know.
You coulda knocked me over with a pin!
Gee, what do you think? There was that watchman, that poor watchman, lying on the floor right in front of me. Oh, you coulda knocked me over with a pin!
Oh - almonds to you! Almonds!
Now, now, Oscar - not almonds!
Hello, Matt. How're you Matt?
I love your jokes, Matt! They're so entertaining! A very funny man!
How are you doing slaves?
Say, did you boys ever hear the story of the pawnbroker with the glass eye?

you can tell me which is my glass eye." The fellow said, "All right, I'll do that. It's the right one." The pawnbroker said, "That's correct. But how did you know it was the right one?" The fellow   ? 105 ?
Sympathy! You know, the right one had more sympathy than the other one!
Six reasons why banks fail!
Come on, white collars. The day's started!
You're carrying too much money on you, Hank. You better turn some in tonight.
Okay, Matt.
How are you fixed?
You've got enough?
How much?
It was more than that last week.
Here's twenty-five thousand.
Say, do me a favor, will you Charlie?
Let me have ten bucks?
Charlie!
Ad-lib conversations from the other clerks distract his attention.
It'll be yours if you don't kick in with that ten bucks.
Aw, nerts!
I'm not asking you to pay off the Depression. I'm only asking you for ten bucks!
That mug reminds me of a guy with his second dollar.
Bought himself a pocketbook!
Hello, Helen!
Why?
Hey, look out, somebody's likely to see us!
With what?
A friend of mine - yeah, really - his mother was terribly sick and she was dying, would you believe it?
Oh, you think I'm lying?
All right, I'm lying. Don't forget you called me a liar.
Oh honey, why don't we get married? Then you can handle it all.
No, what?
Oh, you're kidding me, aren't you?
If that's on the level, there goes my assistant cashier's job.
Yeah, swell.
It's all right. Thanks.
Sure, I think it's swell.
Aw, I'm sorry, Mr. Dickson. It's just kind of sudden, that's all.
Sure, I'm excited. I think it's great. Only, well, you've done so much for me already . . . I'll never be able to thank you enough.
Yeah.
Come here.
You know, a few minutes ago I was in Cluett's office and Mrs. Dickson was there.
Well, he was making love to her.
I tell you, I saw them!
Yes, right in his office, the rat. I'd like to take a crack at that guy.
Everybody in?
Where's Charlie?
Oh, Charlie again.
Can you imagine that guy? He was kissing her.
All right, dear.
Where you been?
What's the matter, Charlie?
I remember once when your account checked.
And listen, wise guy - I'm setting friend time clock for exactly nine o'clock, so no squawks out of you guys in the morning.
Yes, sir.
Now?
All right, sir.
The butler said I could stay. I told him it was important.
He's not here. He left at nine o'clock. He said you gave him the night off.
Well, I thought I'd like to have a little talk with you.
It's funny - now that I'm here, I don't know just how to go about it.
You see, I kind of expected to find you here alone.
Oh no, Mr. Cluett, if it's all the same to you, I'd rather not wait. It's about you and Mrs. Dickson.
I know I've got a lot of nerve butting in like this, but I just couldn't help it. I thought I could stop two people from doing something they'd be sorry for.
You've no right to do this to her, Mr. Cluett. Why don't you think it over? It's only gonna get you into a lot of trouble.
No? Then maybe you'll understand, Mrs. Dickson. Oh, gee, he's crazy about you. Nobody knows it better than you. If he ever finds out, it'll kill him.
This is my business. Mr. Dickson's been like a father to me.
What has he ever done to you to deserve a deal like this?
I'm just wasting my breath talking to you.

Before he finishes the sentence, Cluett punches him. Matt, caught unawares, is thrown off balance and sent reeling. He drops between two chairs. Now, livid with rage, he pulls himself up, murder in his eyes. Cluett crosses quickly to a desk near the door, opens a drawer and extracts a revolver.
You better carry that around with you all the time - you're going to need it.
I didn't do it. I told you all I know, Inspector.
I didn't do it! I haven't got a gun!
I did. I set it for nine o'clock this morning.
I don't know.
I already told him I was home.
Yes.
Well, about - uh - eleven o'clock.
Yes.
Aw, she doesn't know what she's talking about.
Aw, she was right. I didn't get in till after one o'clock.
But I wasn't here, Mr. Dickson. Honest I wasn't . . .
I can't tell you.
No. I won't.
No, I'm not Mr. Dickson!
Don't cry, honey. Everything's gonna be all right.
What's he doing, honey? Is he getting any help?
They must have turned him down.
Sure, they'd turn him down. He ought to know that. I'm going in there and talk to him.
We haven't got much time left, Mr. Dickson. We've got to do something quick or it'll be too late.
You're not giving up, are you, Mr. Dickson?
Oh, I can explain about that later. You're losing your bank - don't you realize what that means?
Well . . . uh . . . I . . .
Yeah.
I got an idea. Come on, let's get to a telephone.
Dickson's in a jam I tell you. The run's getting worse.
The big guys have got the screws on him. You've got to come through for him, Mr. Conway. He came through for you a hundred times. If his friends don't help him, who is going to help him?
They're starting to come in already. Yeah. Yeah. Well, listen. Don't waste any time. Get all the money you can lay your hands on, and bring it down here right away. Step on it.
Who's this?
Mr. Williams?
Mr. Gunther?
I'll talk to both of them at once.

Listen, both you fellows. Dickson's in a jam. The run's getting worse. Those big guys got the screws on him. Yeah, both you fellows got to come thru for him. Listen, if his friends don't help him, who is going to help him? Now he came through for you a hundred times. Yeah, listen. They're starting to come in already. Yeah, listen. Both of you fellas - get all the money you can lay your hands on, and bring it down here right away. Both of you - step on it! All right.
Replies.Didascalie: (holding both phones up to his mouth)

Replies.Reply: Well, I suppose you guys had a good run for your money yesterday!
But I haven't . . .
Come, on slave.
Matt, come here!
Come here, honey!
Oh, is that so?
Search me.
Not yet, Mr. Clark.
Yes, sir.
Yes, sir.
Takes more than two tons of directors to make trouble for my boss.
What did you do with it?
The ten dollars.
Yes.
No.
Yes.
Oh, Matt.
I haven't heard about it.
Good morning.
I don't know.
Why, the directors are waiting for you in the board room.
Longer.
Hello . . .
Mrs. Dickson on the phone.
Hey Pat, come here! Look!
I wonder what he's doing with Mr. Cluett.
How-do-you-do, Mrs. Dickson.
He's at a board meeting.
Board meeting. Oh, that means hours, I suppose.
I'm afraid so.
No.
Hardly.
All right.
Yes, sir.
Matt, where have you been? Mr. Dickson wants to see you right away. Hurry up!
Say, I just heard the merger isn't going thru. Isn't that grand?
What happened? What did he say? Did you get the job?
What's the matter, Matt? Gee, I thought you'd be thrilled to death.
Well . . . ?
Oh Matt, you must be mistaken.
In Cluett's office?
Wait a minute. Now don't go away . . .
Replies.Didascalie: (as she goes to answer the phone)

Replies.Reply: What's keeping you?
Say Matt, you haven't done anything about what you saw today, have you?
Oh now, don't be silly.
Now you've got me worried, dear.
Promise me you won't butt in.
Shh . . . !
I'll wait for you upstairs.
Oh, Mr. Dickson - they're going to arrest Matt. They think he did it!
In Mr. Sampson's office.
Yes, sir.
Oh, Matt . . .
Did you say Dude Finlay?
He was in the bank yesterday.
He came to see Mr. Cluett.
Yes, sir.
You want the rest of those numbers, Mr. Dickson?
Something's happened. He isn't trying anymore.
Yes. He called some of the biggest people in town.
Did you talk to him?
Mr. Williams . . .
Matt, look! There's Mr. Jones!
Replies.Didascalie: (looking up from her own phone pitch)

Replies.Reply: Good morning.
Oh!
Oh, oh. Look who's here.
That's Dude Finlay, all right - I've seen his picture in the papers hundreds of times.
Gee, I'm scared. He's one of the toughest gangsters in town.
What are they doing here? There's no board meeting today.
Looks like trouble for your boss.
Sez you!
Mr. Dickson in yet?
When he comes in, tell him we're waiting for him in the board room.
And tell him not to delay.
I've sent for the cashier, gentlemen. He has a list of the loans that Dickson made last month.
And as I told you at breakfast, it is time we did something about it.
Oh, is he? We carry more unsecured paper than any other institution in the city. We're fools to tolerate it.
What good will that do? Why, it will take control away from him. We'll put somebody else in charge, call in all doubtful loans, and be on safe ground again. That's what good it will do!
He'll stand for it, if I have anything to say about it.
Yes, thank you.
No. Nothing.

Look at this. Just look at this. It's outrageous. Henry Moore - thirty-six thousand. Manny Goldberg - eighty-five hundred. Tony Consero - fifty-six thousand dollars. Joseph McDonald - eighteen thousand. Alvin Jones - sixty-six thousand dollars to a hotel that's on its last legs. I tell you, people get loans in this bank that couldn't borrow five cents anywhere else.
He's almost done that already. Our chief teller, Matt Brown, is an example of that. He breaks into Dickson's house, holds him up, and the next day gets a job in the bank.
Gentlemen, let's get organized before Dickson gets here. Schultz, can I count on you?
What about you, Ames?
Ives, how about you?
All right. O'Brien?
Gentlemen, I think it's time that we do fight.
I think, Mr. Dickson, we would like to have a little of your very valuable time here at the bank this morning, if you don't mind.
How are you protecting your depositors? By making a lot of idiotic loans!
Take it easy, Clark.
All right. I'll speak my piece. Dickson, you've got to change your policy.
Just pure luck!
Who are we going to give it to? Men like Jones? Last week you made him an extra loan of fifty thousand dollars. Do you call that intelligent banking?
Character, hmmpf! That's your idea?
I know, Dickson. That's all very well. But you're taking too many chances. In these times a bank should keep liquid in case of trouble. In case of emergency!
In the meantime, you're jeopardizing the safety of the bank. Well, we won't stand for it!

Gentlemen, you notice Mr. Dickson refuses to consider our wishes. He refuses an offer to merge with the New York Trust - the only thing that will put this bank on safe ground. He insists upon running a bank on so flimsy a thing as . . . as faith!
Mr. Dickson!
We want to talk to you.
We'll discuss that in the board room.
What do you mean, help?
That sounds very simple, Dickson, but why should we jeopardize our personal fortunes?
Oh, is it? Since when? Judging from the way you've ignored us, you wouldn't think so.
Replies.Didascalie: (this is just what he's been waiting for)

Replies.Reply: The depositors you were protecting were the first ones to pounce on you. You thought they were your friends. Why don't you go out there now and try and get some help from them?

No. You can't reason with anyone else when you're in a jam. We pleaded with you to keep liquid, but you wouldn't listen to us. You preached to us about faith and a lot of other rubbish. Now you want our help. You want us to throw a lot of cash into a bank that you've   ? 173 ?
All right, let him! I'm sick and tired of hearing about him. If he wants to run the bank, let him do it. I don't want any part of it.
Oh, shut up!
All right, I'll go and have a talk with him.
Oh, Dickson . . .
Dickson, I'd like to talk to you about the bank.
Now you're talking sense.
We'll draw up the option on your stock - say, eighty dollars a share. How's that?
Good, good. I'll draw it up at once.
shares of stock of this company, now registered in the name of Thomas A. Dickson. Now make that in triplicate and get it to me just as fast as you can. Hurry!
Oh, I don't agree with you, but if everybody's gone crazy, I'll go crazy too!
Send all your available cash to Union National!
Mr. Clark's right. Dickson will ruin this bank if we don't stop him.
That's what I say. And the only way to end it is to get Dickson out.
And on what? "Hunches," he calls it.
A boy who should be in jail, handling a bank's cash!
Absolutely.
You can make a handsome profit on your stock.
He can't pay his bills. How do you expect him to pay us?
You're forcing us to take action against you, Dickson.
We're still waiting for you, Dickson.
We tried to reason with you, but you wouldn't listen to us.
You have no choice.
Look at that mob. They're going crazy.
How much longer is Dickson going to hold out?
Maybe they're right, Clark.
This is your bank, Dickson, and I'm with you!
This is Ben Schultz talking. Send a hundred thousand cash over here to the Union National right away.
Looks to me as if we're in hot water already.
Some day he'll get a "hunch" about a man and give the bank away.
That's the way I feel about it.
Conditions have changed. These are precarious times. Banks today have got to be careful. And you've been more liberal than ever.
Why, Disraeli didn't say anything of the kind.
You know, this run isn't doing the reputation of this bank any good.
If we close our doors, our stock won't be worth a nickel.
I'm sold.
O'BRIEN  Personally, I think you're getting panic-stricken about nothing. Dickson's all right.
Replies.Didascalie: (O'Brien is always filing his nails, even while he talks.)

Replies.Reply: You're wasting your time, I tell you. Dickson won't stand for it.
Oh, I say, that would be . . .
My dear friends . . .
But my dear friends . . .
I'll lay you ten to one, Dickson won't give in.
My dear friends, that's what I've been trying to say all afternoon.
Say, I want one hundred and fifty thousand dollars over here right away.
I am in my right mind. No, no, no. Not one hundred and fifty dollars. Say, listen you guys, one hundred and fifty thousand dollars. Yes!
Here's the list.
Anything else?
Good morning! Who do you want to see?
Oh, yes. Well, come right this way.
I know, I know, Dude. Oh, I must have been crazy! I lost my head completely!
I haven't got it.
But after all, you can't take blood from a stone.
Why, I couldn't do that . . . !
What do you mean?

Smack! The rest of his speech dies in his throat. The man to his right has slapped him across the face with his open palm. Taken unaware, Cluett's hand goes to his cheek. He stares at them, bewildered and frightened.
Dude - there's not any chance of my becoming involved in this, is there?
But Dude, listen - couldn't we make this some other time?
Oh, hello, Phyllis.
Want one?
Heavens, no! Do you mind putting up with me until the financial genius gets thru genius-ing?
No, no, of course not. Not at all. Oh, here.
Am I? Why, I - I don't know any reason why I should be, unless of course it's you . . .
Being alone with you has always done this to me. You know that.
Well, you can. You always could.
Liar! You're just suffering from lack of sleep.
What is?
You'd better start reforming, Cyril!
If I thought you were the slightest bit interested, I would.
Line?
But you see, it isn't blarney where you're concerned.
Now let me see, what comes next?
Oh yes, I know - what are you doing tonight, Phyllis?
Tonight?
Yes, yes, it does. What are you doing tonight, Phyllis?
Oh! Oh, no! I think I've done enough experimenting for one day. Congratulations, Cyril. You've convinced me that you're a philanderer of the very first order. I shall recommend you highly.
Please, please don't laugh at me, Phyllis. I must see you tonight!
Well, what?
Well, aren't you going to invite me?
You? No can do. It's all set. Just a few of Tom's closest friends.
Now Phyllis, if you don't invite me, I'm coming anyway.
No, they won't. Not when you are there. Oh, please, be a sport. Please ask me.
Why are you so anxious?
Don't you know?
I want to be near you!
Don't you know I've been crazy about you for years?
Now wait a minute, wait a minute . . .
I've loved you ever since I can remember, long before you married Tom Dickson.
MRS. DICKSON  Cyril!
Please forgive me, Phyllis. I lost my head for a minute. But I couldn't help it, Phyllis.
Are the payrolls ready for tomorrow?
Let me see your cash book, will you?
Yes, now.
That's all right. But it seems to me you're carrying too much cash.
Driver?
Have you the correct time?
What's this?
My apartment.
Come on up for just a few minutes. We'll have just one drink, then we'll go.
No. I know the answer to that one.
I think you'd better take me home.
What's the matter? Afraid papa will spank?
I think I will have a drink.
Good for you. Come on.
Oh, you're not so badly off. There's something much worse than being a misunderstood wife.
A misunderstood bachelor.
And now fair woman, I have you in my power.
I'm not afraid of you. You haven't got a moustache!
I'll grow a moustache by the time you get out of here.
What are you doing here?
Oh, yeah?
What do you want?
I'm listening.
Anything you have to say to me, you can say in the morning.
About me and . . .
I'm not interested in what you think.
I tell you, I'm not interested in your opinion.
Phyllis, you don't have to explain anything.
You'd do well to mind your own business.
That will be just about enough! Now get out of here!
You're right for the first time. Now get out!
Now get out of here!
You needn't go on account of this idiot.
Of course, yes. Just what would you like to know, Inspector?
That's very simple. I was home.
Oh yes, of course. There was someone with me. A lady.
If you don't mind, Inspector, I'd rather not say - that is, unless it becomes absolutely essential. You see, she's married.
You understand?
Pardon me.
Hello . . . who? Yes, he's here.
It's for you, Inspector.
Somebody must be in good humor. He was humming "Mother Machree."
Stand back Inspector, or I'll shoot. Drop that gun.
Stand back, Inspector. Let me out of here, or I'll shoot you!
I warn you, Inspector - I'll shoot!
A shot is heard. The gun drops out of Cluett's hand. His arm goes limp. His face screws up in pain.
I don't know. It's all been like a crazy nightmare, Mr. Dickson.
Gambling - I owed them a lot of money. Last week I lost over fifty thousand dollars!
But I didn't kill that man last night. Honest I didn't, Mr. Dickson!
Yesterday they came to collect it. I begged them to wait. I wanted time to think, but they wouldn't listen to me.
They threatened to kill me if I didn't pay it! I was desperate! I didn't know what to do!
I didn't know anybody was going to be killed!
They took my keys yesterday. I went there to get them back.
I was crazy, I tell you, Mr. Dickson. I didn't know what I was doing. I wandered around in a daze. All I could think of was that they were going to kill me . . .
You'll stand by me, won't you, Mr. Dickson? You won't go back on me now, will you? I'll die if they send me to prison!
I didn't kill him! I had nothing to do with that, I tell you! I was home in my apartment last night - I can prove it!
He stops dead. Suddenly he realizes what he is saying.
Nothing, nothing, Mr. Dickson. Don't pay any attention to me. I don't know what I'm saying.
She just came up for a drink. Just for a few minutes.
Hello, Gardiner.
The check is no good. The man has no account here.
I'm sorry, madam.
Was there much blood?
Say, did Matt do it?
Good morning. You're on time this morning. It's about time.
Good morning, Mr. Dickson.
Much better this morning, thank you.
I'm feeling fine this morning.
Thank you!
Shall we let the people come in?
Good morning, Mr. Dickson. My wife is much better this morning.
John, how's your wife this morning?
Got a handkerchief?
Wait a minute.
How do you feel this morning?
Replies.Didascalie: (he takes the handkerchief, and polishes the brass on Gardiner's uniform)

Replies.Reply: That makes it unanimous. I feel all right too.
Oh, Carter!
You know the rules about smoking . . .
Oh, Matt!
He is joined by Bill Saunders, a friend of his. Bill walks along with Dickson.
You here again? What do you want?
Listen, I told you I wasn't interested in that deal, didn't I?
Wait a minute. Where's your uniform?
You haven't got a uniform?
My goodness, you ought to have a uniform. How much does one cost?
You see Sampson. Tell him I sent you. You've got to have a uniform.
I'll tell you why. I don't like the crowd you're mixed up with.
Personally, you can have all the credit you want. But for that deal - not a cent.
Good morning, Mrs. Pembroke.
Got my letter?
Hello, Helen.
Helen, you're becoming more beautiful every day. What are we going to do about it?
Guess we'll just have to sacrifice the bank. When are you and Matt going to get married?
Ummm. Stalling, eh?
Anything new?
Directors, eh? Long faces?
I haven't got any new stories for them this morning, either.
Ah, Mrs. Pembroke. I spoke to Mr. Schaffer at the Guaranty. He's going to take care of that mortgage for you . . .
You'd better hurry over there. He's waiting for you.
Hello, dear . . .
Where are you? . . . Sure, well, come on down right away. Huh? . . . Yes, of course I remember. It's tonight.
See what a social hound I'm becoming! . . . All right, goodbye, dear.
Mr. Schaffer will take good care of you. He'll give you fifteen - maybe twenty . . .
Better hurry now. Goodbye. Good luck to you!
Oh, if Mrs. Dickson comes in, will you tell her to see Cluett if she needs any money?
She's a widow. I don't like taking mortgages from widows.
If she can't pay, I'll have to foreclose, won't I?
Yeah - sure!
Oh, make that uniform blue.
One - two - three - four - five. Seven more and you'd have a jury!
Well, it's a nice morning, gentlemen. How about two foursomes of golf?
Oh, you would, eh? All right. If it's more important than golf, go ahead. What's on your mind?
Gentlemen, you're only wasting your time. There'll be no merger.
Nothing doing!
I'm not interested in profits. I'm interested in the bank. In the depositors. They're my friends. They're looking to me for protection, and I'm not walking out on them.
It's all right. Let him go ahead. Let him speak his piece. I like it. Go on.
What's the matter with my policy? How many losses has this bank taken in the last twenty-five years?

The trouble with this country today is there's too much hoarded cash. Idle money is no good to industry. Where is all the money today? In the banks, vaults, socks, old tin cans, buried in the ground! I tell you, we've got to get the money in circulation before you'll get this country back to prosperity.

That's a fair question, Schultz. Now let's see how bad a risk Jones is. What's his history? He's been a successful business man for thirty-five years. Two years ago business started falling off. Today Jones needs money, and if he doesn't get it, he goes into bankruptcy and throws nine hundred men out of work. Answer - unemployment.

It's a vicious circle, my friends, and the only place to cure it is right here at the source. Help Jones and you help the whole circle. Now, when Jones comes to me, I ask myself two questions. First - is he honest? Yes. Second - is he as good a business man as he was before? And the answer is - he's better .
Well, he should have said it. It's as true now as it was then. And let us get the right kind of security. Not stocks and bonds that zig-zag up and down, not collateral on paper, but character!
country has ever known. Those are his exact words, gentlemen. Character! It's the only thing you can bank on, and it's the only thing that will pull this country out of the doldrums.
Most of the creditors I know personally. I've seen them grow up in the community. I knew their fathers and mothers before them.

I know what you mean by that. You want me to hang on to our cash. Well, I don't believe in it. The law demands that I carry a certain legal reserve, and I'm doing it. The rest of our money is out working . . . working to help industry . . . to help build up business . . .
You have to stand for it.
Go ahead - take all the action you want!
I'm running this bank my way. Get that clear!
Yes! You said it, Clark. That's the only thing that means anything to me.
So far, my judgement has been right one hundred per cent. One hundred per cent! When I start going wrong, you won't have to take any action. I'll turn the bank over to you. Then you can  ? 134 ?
Helen, tell Matt I want to see him.
Well, Matt, get ready for the big moment. Starting tomorrow you become assistant cashier. How's that?
And what's more, keep up the good work and who knows - some day you'll be the fellow sitting behind that desk . . .
Not a bad thought, eh?
What's the matter? You don't seem very excited about it.
Say, come on. Show a little enthusiasm. What's the matter? Are you sick or something? Go on, fake it - even if it isn't real.

Aw, go on, forget it. You came through, didn't you? That's all I wanted. A lot of them didn't think you would. You don't know how much satisfaction it's been to me. It's been swell. Well, when are you and Helen going to get married?
I suppose you want me to fix that up for you too, eh?
Well, look who's here! Hello, dear.

If this isn't a red-letter day for Tom Dickson! First I trample on the Board of Directors, then I promote Matt here to assistant cashier, and now to complete the day I have a visit from my sweet and lovely and gorgeous wife. What a man, what a man!
Oooh! That has the earmarks!
Are you still here? Go on - go to work! What do you think I pay you for?

Yes George . . . yes, sure . . . Oh, that's for tonight, eh? . . . Yes, certainly, I'll be there . . . Yes, we'll go down together and have dinner in Philadelphia . . . Mrs. Dickson gets so upset . . . That's right. . . . Yeah. . . . Just as soon as the bank closes. . . . Right. . . . Goodbye. . . .
Replies.Didascalie: (talking on the phone, as Mrs Dickson waits patiently)

Replies.Reply: Helen, I'm going to Philadelphia, just as soon as the bank closes. Make all the arrangements, will you?
What's the matter dear? What have I done now?
Oh, I did have a date with you tonight, didn't I?
I'm terribly sorry. I'd forgotten all about you. I'm so sorry, dear.
But I have to go, dear. It's a very important banker's meeting.
Listen, it isn't so terribly important. We can go to the theatre any time.
That's what it was you planned, wasn't it?
Yes, of course.
MRS. DICKSON  The girls! I don't suppose it ever occurred to you that I might go out and find myself an attractive young man . . .
Ho! Ho! Ho!
Listen, don't go around being attractive to anyone but me . . .
Don't you forget that I'm still the head man around here too. Now we'll get the tickets changed for tomorrow night. You and I are going out together. How's that?
Yes?
Oh, yes. That's that lawyer. All right, let him have nine thousand.

Yes sir, I'll step you around this town like you've never stepped before. We will have dinner at the St. Regis - then we'll go to a nice, snappy show - then a nightclub - we'll listen to soft music, and who knows? Ha! - I might break down and dance with you!
All right. I'll postpone the whole thing until tomorrow night.
Happy now?
Poor kid, you know, I have been neglecting you.
Yes?
All right. Send him in.
Well, Sampson, what is it?
Good. I'll take this along with me. Tell Clyde I'll see him tomorrow. I'm sick and tired of the delay.
That's just exactly what he has been doing. This deal should have been closed weeks ago. Tell him to keep tomorrow open . . .
How about his nights? He's too busy running around. Tell him to keep tomorrow night open, come in and sign this thing, or I'll call this whole deal off.
Good morning, everybody. What's the matter here? Open up the door. Come on, open this door.
Of course, let them in! You're late now.
Where is he now?
Now don't you worry about it.
What's the matter? What's going on here?
This is ridiculous! You can't hold this boy on a vague suspicion.
Why pick on him ?
Yes.
Wait a minute. Wait a minute.
What time did this thing happen?
All right. If the boy proves an alibi, he's all right, isn't he?
Why, certainly he can.
Matt, now all you've got to do is tell them where you were last night, between twelve and twelve-thirty, and everything will be all right.
There you are.
Good.
You've got nothing to worry about. Soon as the report comes in, you'll be released.
And listen, don't talk so loud. Take it easy. Coast a little.
What are you talking about? He had no more to do with it than you did.
He is interrupted by the sound of the door opening. He looks off toward door.
What? A run on the bank!
What are you talking about?
All right. Send down to the vaults and have our reserve cash sent up here right away.

The bank's reputation wouldn't be worth a nickel after that. This is just a flurry, that's all. They've heard about the robbery and got panic-stricken. Listen, get ahold of our available securities and have them turned into cash. Wait a minute. Get my personal stuff and have that turned into cash too. Tell the boys anyone caught arguing with a depositor will be fired on the spot.
What about?
All right.
I'll be with you in a minute, Clark.
Now don't worry, son. All you got to do is answer the questions they ask you, that's all.
Is that true, Matt?
Listen, Matt. If you don't tell the truth, I can't help you. Where were you last night?
Wait a minute. Wait a minute.
Matt, do you realize you're up against something? You're being charged with murder. It's serious, son. Now come on, I know you didn't do it.
But we've got to make them believe it. Come on, tell the truth, where were you last night?
Listen, if I get them out of the room, will you tell me ?
You're protecting somebody.
Yes, you are. You're protecting somebody. Now listen, it doesn't make any difference who it is. It can't be as important as this. Now come on, tell me. Where were you last night?
Come on, don't be a fool. Matt, you trust me, don't you?
Did you get the case for the securities?
Mine too?
The fools! If they only knew it, they're making things worse for themselves. Somebody starts a silly rumor, and they lose their heads.
I'll talk to them. Listen, go back and tell the boys to stall as much as possible. Tell 'em not to pay any attention to what I said. Tell 'em to verify every signature.
Take your time, folks. Don't get excited. Everybody stay in line. You'll all be taken care of. Don't worry about anything. Plenty of time for everything.
Now listen, everybody! Listen to me!
I want you to know that your money is safe. This bank is in excellent condition. If you've heard any reports to the contrary, it's based on malicious rumors.
All right. You'll get your money - every penny!

Listen to me now. It takes time. I've got seven paying tellers working just as fast as they can. If you'll all calm down, I'm making arrangements to keep the doors open until four o'clock this afternoon and you can be paid today.
Don't you think I know it?
Well, gentlemen, we've got about one more hour to go. You know what that means?
We'll be forced to shut the doors. I've worked twenty-five years night and day to keep this bank alive. You've all made money out of it. Are you willing to help?
I know that among you, you have at least a million dollars in various banks throughout the city. Get that money over here and I'll stop this run within five minutes.
I have everything I own in it. It's your bank as well as mine, isn't it?
Aw, they've gone crazy. You can't reason with a mob.
So, that's it, eh? You've waited a long time for this chance, haven't you?
Well, I'm not going to resign now - or ever.
I haven't? I'll shut the bank first.

I can't? You just wait and see. If that run doesn't stop within the next hour, I'll shut the doors. You know what that means? The bank examiner will step in tomorrow. You'll be forced to liquidate. I'll insist upon it. The depositors will be paid one hundred cents on the dollar. What's left you gentlemen can have. But I'll guarantee there won't be enough to pay your next month's garage bill.

Get all the big bills in the place. Take them out and get them changed. Get nothing but ones and fives. Distribute them among the tellers. Tell them to take their time. Stall as much as possible. Count and recount the money.
I hate to do this, but I've got to have time to dig up some help. I think I know where I can get some real cash. Snap into it, Sampson. We will lick this thing yet.

Come on in here, Helen. Bring your book. I want some numbers to try to get some action. Get Parker at the Union-Leeds - the Exchange . . . Winslow and old man Harris at the Home Mortgage. Snap into it, Helen. Just as quick as you can.
Hello, Parker. Listen. Listen, I've got to have a million dollars in cash, and I've got to have it quick.
What?
No, no, no. Tomorrow is no good. I need it now.
Of course it's safe. Why, the bank's in excellent condition. You know that.
Good heavens, man, you're taking no chances. No, I'm perfectly willing to sign everything over to you. What more do you want? I need action. I've got to have it within the next half hour.
Yeah, sure - the board of directors turned me down, but you know why.
Listen. Listen, read it. It wouldn't be a drop in the bucket to you.
You can't do a thing. You're up to your neck. All right.
Why, you must be crazy. I've known this man for years.
Confessed! Cluett, in heaven's name, what got into you?
What happened? You're not a thief. How'd you get mixed up with these kind of people?
Fifty thousand dollars!
If you were in a jam, why didn't you come to me? I would have helped you out. You know that.
My wife? What's she got to do with you?
What was my wife doing in your apartment last night?
You just mentioned her name. What was she doing there? What was she doing in your apartment?
You're lying!
You don't want to check up on anybody. I'll do all the checking up. Wait a minute.
Helen!
Get Mrs. Dickson on the phone.
Listen, dear. I want to ask you something. I know it's a silly thing for me to ask you, but . . . I want you to tell me the truth. Where were you last night?
Last night? Er - why - uh, last night . . .
Listen, dear. Now tell me the truth about this. Were you in Cluett's apartment?
In Cluett's apartment? Well dear, you see, I . . . I . . .
Get out, get out!
The bank. All right. Do anything you want with it.
Eighty dollars? That's fine - anything you say.
Numbers? No, never mind.
Why wouldn't you tell me where you were last night?
Were you in Cluett's apartment?
Was Mrs. Dickson there?
Wait a minute. Answer my question. Was Mrs. Dickson there?
All right. That's all.
Please, Matt.
Come out here you pawnbrokers - take a look at this!
You know what you can do with that! Come on, take a look at this! You'll see a demonstration of faith that's worth more than all the collateral in the world.
Look at that. They're shoving their hard-earned money across the counter with a ten to one chance against them.
If you fellas want to save this bank, get some real money over here right away.
That's enough for me, Dickson. I'm ashamed of myself. I'll have a hundred thousand dollars over here in five minutes.
Now you're talking! Ames?
All right. Schultz?
Ives?
Go ahead and say it.
Clark, you can do twice as much as any of them. How about you?
Well, that's too bad. Mine's all right too.
Carter!
Well, well, well - got your uniform, eh?
Looks good. How much did it cost?
Oh-oh. I guess I'll have to see Sampson myself.
Good morning, Helen.
Say, I know what's the matter with you. Matt!
I want you both to take the day off. Go downtown and get a license and get married right away!
I don't want to hear any more about it. If you don't get married, I'll fire both of you.
next week.
Oh, no! It's not for you. You're only going to get married. Mrs. Dickson and I are going to go on the honeymoon.
Yes sir?
Thank you, sir.
Hello, Tom.
What do you suppose anybody wants? Money, money, money!
I want to know why .
They have now reached the anteroom of Dickson's private chamber, where Helen sits at her desk.
What's the idea of turning her down? It sounds like a perfectly safe investment.
Why not?
I haven't any.
No, sir.
Why, I don't know.
Yes, sir.
Yes, sir.
I don't know. Mr. Sampson bought it for me.
Holy mackerel! I've been robbed.
So am I. And don't call me madam!
Yes, ma'am, you can deposit your money here.
Absolutely.
Quiet down, please! Take it easy, folks. Everything will be all right.
Please, lady. Please be quiet. Everything will be all right.
Yes, ma'am. He must be in there. He hasn't come out.
Yes, I think there's one right here in the drawer.
Is it safe?
It's his life insurance money, you know.
But you said it would be safe! It's his life insurance money. Oh, please, I'll go to the Old Ladies' Home if you don't do something, please!
That's all right. You come with me, and I'll show you where to deposit your money.
There he is! Good morning!
You.
Yeah. We wanna talk to you about a big deal.
You know what we do to welchers, Cluett, don't you?
That's your funeral. We've got fifty thousand dollars comin' to us.
Then what did you want to gamble for? If you'd have beat us out of fifty G's, you'd have been paid, wouldn't you? Well, we want our dough.
That don't do us any good.
If it's comin' to us.
Nix. Lay off.
Now - what's the use of getting excited, Cluett? It oughta be easy for you to lay your mitts on that kind of dough . . .
There's plenty of it in this bank - laying around loose.
Why not?
You don't have to do nothing.
All you gotta do is fix a few things for us , and we'll do the rest, see?
You? No, you'll be all right, so long as you establish an alibi for tonight.
Be sure you're with somebody responsible in case any questions are asked. Understand?
Listen, buddy, you're getting by pretty easy. Quit squawking!
Mr. Gardner's here.
Here's the data on the Clyde deal.
I'm afraid he's been stalling.
He says he can't get away in the daytime.
Yes, sir.
Pardon me, but I'd like to use my office for awhile!
I know, I know. I'll get you some.
Mr. Dickson! Can I see you for a minute?
But this is important, Mr. Dickson. Looks like there's a run on the bank.
The lobby's half filled now.
Look!
They've been coming in steady all morning. I have called for some extra police.
We haven't much on hand, you know. If it gets any worse, I hope we don't have to close the doors.
Yes, sir.
Look at them, Mr. Dickson. They're going crazy.
Yes, sir.
Yes, sir. But soon as our money runs out, they'll mob the place.
What'll we do?
We can't keep open till four o'clock. We haven't cash enough to last an hour.
Mr. Dickson! Mr. Dickson!
Yes, sir.
Stall! Stall!
Mr. Dickson! Come here a minute. Look at this. Something wonderful has happened. People are bringing deposits. You won't believe it until you see it. You have to come out.
Look!
Good night. Good night, Matt.

Hello, dear . . . Hurry! . . . Union National is sunk! . . . I told you to put it in the vault . . . I don't know what's wrong with the bank . . . I wouldn't trust anybody . . . everybody's taking their money out . . . Union National's broken . . . Why take any chances? . . . Hurry! Call the others! etc.
Why Matt, what are you talking about?
What do you say, Doc?
Well, you'd better call the coroner.
Get back there . I don't want anything touched until the Inspector gets here.
Oh, Mr. Dickson! We got a check on Brown's alibi. Do you want to hear it?
Is the chief's car outside?
Sorry, sister.
There he goes!
He must be here. There's only one door.
Sounded like a locker.
Oh, I'd say about eight or nine hours.
Yeah, he did. I noticed it too.
You turned off the burglar alarm, you set the time clock, came back at twelve and emptied the boxes, didn't you?
Sit down! When the watchman surprised you, you shot him - what'd you do with the gun?
You used to carry a gun, didn't you?
You use some other office!
Dickson enters.
I'm afraid I must, Mr. Dickson.
It's an inside job. That's a cinch. Whoever did it had a pretty good picture of the layout. Now Brown, here, is in charge of the vaults, isn't he?
Then who changed it?
If he can do it, yes.
That's what he says. I got a man from headquarters checking up on it now.
All I know is the bank's been robbed and a murder's been committed. The way I see it, Brown here looks guilty.
Maybe. But I'm taking no chances.
Why, this kid's got a record.
So you were home last night?
What time did you get in?
Eleven o'clock, eh? Are you sure it was that?
All right, Kelley.
Do you know this young man, Mrs. Halligan?
What time was it?
What time was it, Mrs. Halligan?
What time was it?
What time did Matt Brown get in?
I don't care about the Dooley sisters - what time did he get in?
Was it twelve o'clock?
It couldn't have been earlier?
Yes, I know. Cause the Dooley sisters weren't in yet.
No - because me clock struck four, and when it strikes four, it's one.
There you are!
That's all, Mrs. Halligan. Thanks.
Of course it's true - and he knows it.
Then where were you?
You'd better tell Mr. Dickson we're taking Matt Brown downtown.
Okay. Come on son. Let's go.
What did you find out, Mike?
Never mind all that. What did you find out?
Dude Finlay?
Helen starts out of scene.
Yes, why?
He was here?
Are you sure?
Kelly! You stay here with Brown.
Oh, Kelly - call me up in Cluett's office in about five minutes.
me up.
I hope you don't mind me asking you a few questions, Mr. Cluett.
Where were you at twelve o'clock last night?
That is simple, isn't it? I assume you can prove that if necessary.
Looks like you're going to have no trouble at all. What was the lady's name, Mr. Cluett?
Oh!
Why, of course.
Thanks.
It's one of the boys from headquarters. He always sings "Mother Machree" whenever he's got good news. Looks like this case'll be settled in no time.
Yeah. What? . . . You don't mean Cyril Cluett, the cashier?
The detectives dash out, Inspector following.
All right. Find him.
What was that noise?
A locker, eh? Well, search every one of them. He must be in one of 'em.
All right, Jack, all right.
Don't be a fool, Cluett. This is only going to make it worse for you.
Let me see it! Let me see it! It's only his finger. Get me a towel.
Now take it easy, buddy. Take it easy. All we want to do is talk to you.
You were right, Mr. Dickson! Brown didn't have anything to do with it. Here's your man.
He's just confessed. He's been mixed up with the toughest gangsters in town.
What were you doing at Finlay's this morning?
Don't forget there's a dead watchman downstairs.
Claims he was there with a married woman. Doesn't want to mention her name.
No wonder he didn't want to mention her name.
Don't worry, Mr. Dickson. We'll find out whether he's telling the truth. I'll have a man from headquarters check up on it right away.
All right. Let's go.
Come on, open up!
Who did it?
Call me up later. I'm going to call up Lou now.
Hello, Lou. Did you hear what happened over at the Union National Bank?
Wait a minute, Lou.
Hello? Yes, sir. I'm trying to get them.
Yes, Lou, listen. They was robbed over two hundred thousand dollars. Can you beat that?
I don't know who did it, but the chief teller's in an awful jam.
What a day, Mame! Everybody's coming in and drawing their money out.
Gee, Mame - I wonder what started it.
Good morning. Union National Bank. Just a minute . . .
Stole over a quarter of a million. Can you beat that?
Sammy, are you sure about that?
More than a million dollars?
Never mind my shoes, Sam.
I tell you, I got it from the best authority. Dickson got away with several million dollars.
You said it.
If you've got any money in there, you can just kiss it goodbye.
No, I'm not.
That's a good idea. I have friends of my own.
Listen, Jack, go down to the Union National and take your money out of there. Don't ask me how I know. I told you it's on the rocks. If you've got any friends, you'd better tell them too.
Yes, sir. I'm closing my account. I wouldn't leave a nickel in this bank.
What's the matter, lady?
Well, they only sign slips here.
Will you loan me that pen of yours? I'm in an awful hurry.
It's a lotta hooey! We want our money!
Certainly it's my signature. You've seen it often enough.
Get out of my way. I got money I want to put into the bank.
Tom Dickson is a friend of mine! I'll put money in his bank any time!
That's the trouble with people nowadays. They hear a crazy rumor, and right away they lose their heads. Not me! You didn't see me drawing my money out, did you?
Oh, good gracious!
Yes, suh! That messenga boy just tol' me that Mr. Dickson took it all hisself. And it was more than a million dollars.
Cross my heart. And I sure hopes that man gets a long time in jail, too!
Well, I always said the Union National was a phony bank.
Union National?
You had money in that bank, too?
Mon dieu, mon dieu! Run, run!
Yes. Something wrong?
What bank did you say that was?
Holy smoke! I'll get right down there if I have to fly!
Anybody who takes money out of this bank is crazy! I'm going to put a lot of money in! Here it is!
They're all a bunch of crooks.
Tom Dickson can have all my money any time.
All right. I'll get it or bust a few noses!
Run down there and get your money at once!
Say, did I know the bank was going to go caflooey? What am I - a fortune teller or something?
Oh, my goodness! Oh, my goodness! Oh, my goodness!
Oh, mister, I gotta! I gotta!
Gimme your pen, please!
I've been trailing the cashier like you told me. You're right about that guy, chief. There's something screwy somewhere.
He left here about an hour ago and went down to Dude Finlay's joint.
Yes, sir.
I ain't got nobody here. I'm with Brown. Didn't you tell me to call you up in five minutes?
What? Dude Finlay? Sure, I got him here! You know, for a minute I didn't catch on . . .
Sorry ladies and gentlemen, there's no more money. You'll have to go on to the next window.
That's all there is!
What do you mean there's no more money? etc.

Any bank that Tom Dickson has anything to do with is all right. I'm putting my money in here. Why should you be afraid? Give him a chance. Tom Dickson is all right! He's perfectly square. I'm putting my money in this bank! I know what I'm doing!
Open up! I want to put some money in here! I don't want to take any out!
As Clark and the other directors make their urgent phone calls.
Open up!
As they gather for their morning ritual, waiting for Matt.
